host sex.description: Gender or sex of the host.

pcr conditions.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

host diet.description: type of diet depending on the host, for animals omnivore, herbivore etc., for humans high-fat, meditteranean etc.; can include multiple diet types

host last meal.description: content of last meal and time since feeding; can include multiple values

extrachromosomal elements.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

propagation.description: This field is specific to different taxa. For plants: sexual/asexual, for phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, plasmids and viruses.

pcr primers.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

organism count.description: total count of any organism per gram or volume of sample, should include name of organism followed by count; can include multiple organism counts

known pathogenicity.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

library screening strategy.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

source material identifiers.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

investigation type.description: Nucleic Acid Sequence Report is the root element of all MIxS compliant reports as standardised by Genomic Standards Consortium

library reads sequenced.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

sample storage duration.description: duration for which sample was stored

host age.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

trophic level.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

sample material processing.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

library vector.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

host disease status.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

library construction method.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

validationSchema.author: ENA
validationSchema.title: GSC MIxS human gut
validationSchema.description: Genomic Standards Consortium package extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from the environment where the sample was obtained. By choosing the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from a relevant subsets of the GSC terms.

investigation type.description: Nucleic Acid Sequence Report is the root element of all MIxS compliant reports as standardised by Genomic Standards Consortium

project name.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

experimental factor.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.43) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

ploidy.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

number of replicons.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

extrachromosomal elements.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

estimated size.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

reference for biomaterial.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

finishing strategy.description: Was the genome project intended to produce a complete or draft genome, Coverage, the fold coverage of the sequencing expressed as 2x, 3x, 18x etc, and how many contigs were produced for the genome. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryote, bacteria and archaea.

annotation source.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

sample volume or weight for DNA extracti.description: Volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction

nucleic acid extraction.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

nucleic acid amplification.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

library size.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

library reads sequenced.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

library construction method.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

library vector.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

library screening strategy.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

target gene.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

target subfragment.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

pcr primers.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

multiplex identifiers.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

adapters.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

pcr conditions.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

sequencing method.description: Sequencing method used; e.g. Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid

sequence quality check.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

chimera check.description: A chimeric sequence, or chimera for short, is a sequence comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences. Chimeras are usually PCR artifacts thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to a foreign DNA strand and is copied to completion in the following PCR cycles. The point at which the chimeric sequence changes from one parent to the next is called the breakpoint or conversion point

relevant standard operating procedures.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

human gut environmental package.description: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. All environmental packages listed here are further defined in separate subtables. By giving the name of the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from the subtables and can be reported

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

source material identifiers.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

sample collection device or method.description: The method or deviced employed for collecting the sample

sample material processing.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

isolation and growth condition.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

propagation.description: This field is specific to different taxa. For plants: sexual/asexual, for phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, plasmids and viruses.

amount or size of sample collected.description: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected

host body product.description: substance produced by the body, e.g. stool, mucus, where the sample was obtained from. For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

medical history performed.description: whether full medical history was collected

organism count.description: total count of any organism per gram or volume of sample, should include name of organism followed by count; can include multiple organism counts

sample storage duration.description: duration for which sample was stored

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

sample storage location.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

gastrointestinal tract disorder.description: history of gastrointestinal tract disorders; can include multiple disorders

liver disorder.description: history of liver disorders; can include multiple disorders

host disease status.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

host subject id.description: a unique identifier by which each subject can be referred to, de-identified, e.g. #131

host age.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

host body site.description: name of body site where the sample was obtained from, such as a specific organ or tissue (tongue, lung etc...). For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

host body-mass index.description: body mass index, calculated as weight/(height)squared

host occupation.description: most frequent job performed by subject

host total mass.description: total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host

host phenotype.description: phenotype of host. For Phenotypic quality Ontology (PATO) (v 2013-10-28) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

host body temperature.description: core body temperature of the host when sample was collected

host sex.description: Gender or sex of the host.

temperature.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

sample salinity.description: salinity of sample, i.e. measure of total salt concentration

miscellaneous parameter.description: Any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here

special diet.description: specification of special diet; can include multiple special diets

host diet.description: type of diet depending on the host, for animals omnivore, herbivore etc., for humans high-fat, meditteranean etc.; can include multiple diet types

host last meal.description: content of last meal and time since feeding; can include multiple values

host family relationship.description: relationships to other hosts in the same study; can include multiple relationships

host pulse.description: resting pulse, measured as beats per minute

subspecific genetic lineage.description: This should provide further information about the genetic distinctness of this lineage by recording additional information i.e biovar, serovar, serotype, biovar, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. It can also contain alternative taxonomic information

observed biotic relationship.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

trophic level.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

relationship to oxygen.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

known pathogenicity.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

encoded traits.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

chemical administration.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

perturbation.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

description: Genomic Standards Consortium package extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from the environment where the sample was obtained. By choosing the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from a relevant subsets of the GSC terms.

validationSchema.author: ENA

reference for biomaterial.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

ploidy.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

investigation type.description: Nucleic Acid Sequence Report is the root element of all MIxS compliant reports as standardised by Genomic Standards Consortium

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

amount or size of sample collected.description: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected

sample material processing.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

sample collection device or method.description: The method or deviced employed for collecting the sample

adapters.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

host phenotype.description: phenotype of host. For Phenotypic quality Ontology (PATO) (v 2013-10-28) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

pcr conditions.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

temperature.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

sample storage location.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

time since last toothbrushing.description: specification of the time since last toothbrushing

propagation.description: This field is specific to different taxa. For plants: sexual/asexual, for phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, plasmids and viruses.

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

chimera check.description: A chimeric sequence, or chimera for short, is a sequence comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences. Chimeras are usually PCR artifacts thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to a foreign DNA strand and is copied to completion in the following PCR cycles. The point at which the chimeric sequence changes from one parent to the next is called the breakpoint or conversion point

sample salinity.description: salinity of sample, i.e. measure of total salt concentration

host sex.description: Gender or sex of the host.

extrachromosomal elements.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

nucleic acid extraction.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

sample volume or weight for DNA extracti.description: Volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

library size.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

perturbation.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

pcr primers.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

host body product.description: substance produced by the body, e.g. stool, mucus, where the sample was obtained from. For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

subspecific genetic lineage.description: This should provide further information about the genetic distinctness of this lineage by recording additional information i.e biovar, serovar, serotype, biovar, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. It can also contain alternative taxonomic information

human oral environmental package.description: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. All environmental packages listed here are further defined in separate subtables. By giving the name of the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from the subtables and can be reported

sample storage duration.description: duration for which sample was stored

multiplex identifiers.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

host age.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

medical history performed.description: whether full medical history was collected

annotation source.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

library reads sequenced.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

trophic level.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

host body-mass index.description: body mass index, calculated as weight/(height)squared

host body site.description: name of body site where the sample was obtained from, such as a specific organ or tissue (tongue, lung etc...). For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

host pulse.description: resting pulse, measured as beats per minute

library construction method.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

host last meal.description: content of last meal and time since feeding; can include multiple values

miscellaneous parameter.description: Any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here

project name.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

nucleic acid amplification.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

isolation and growth condition.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

source material identifiers.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

number of replicons.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

sequence quality check.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

host total mass.description: total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host

finishing strategy.description: Was the genome project intended to produce a complete or draft genome, Coverage, the fold coverage of the sequencing expressed as 2x, 3x, 18x etc, and how many contigs were produced for the genome. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryote, bacteria and archaea.

host occupation.description: most frequent job performed by subject

chemical administration.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

host disease status.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

relevant standard operating procedures.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences

host diet.description: type of diet depending on the host, for animals omnivore, herbivore etc., for humans high-fat, meditteranean etc.; can include multiple diet types

relationship to oxygen.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

nose/mouth/teeth/throat disorder.description: history of nose/mouth/teeth/throat disorders; can include multiple disorders

library vector.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

estimated size.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

known pathogenicity.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

host subject id.description: a unique identifier by which each subject can be referred to, de-identified, e.g. #131

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

experimental factor.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.43) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

target subfragment.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

host body temperature.description: core body temperature of the host when sample was collected

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

organism count.description: total count of any organism per gram or volume of sample, should include name of organism followed by count; can include multiple organism counts

library screening strategy.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

encoded traits.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

observed biotic relationship.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

host family relationship.description: relationships to other hosts in the same study; can include multiple relationships

target gene.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

sequencing method.description: Sequencing method used; e.g. Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid

validationSchema.title: GSC MIxS human oral

sample material processing.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

reference for biomaterial.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

project name.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

nucleic acid amplification.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

amount or size of sample collected.description: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected

sequencing method.description: Sequencing method used; e.g. Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid

encoded traits.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

miscellaneous parameter.description: Any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

trophic level.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

host diet.description: type of diet depending on the host, for animals omnivore, herbivore etc., for humans high-fat, meditteranean etc.; can include multiple diet types

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

isolation and growth condition.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

target subfragment.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

host age.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

sample storage duration.description: duration for which sample was stored

chimera check.description: A chimeric sequence, or chimera for short, is a sequence comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences. Chimeras are usually PCR artifacts thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to a foreign DNA strand and is copied to completion in the following PCR cycles. The point at which the chimeric sequence changes from one parent to the next is called the breakpoint or conversion point

host occupation.description: most frequent job performed by subject

sample salinity.description: salinity of sample, i.e. measure of total salt concentration

nucleic acid extraction.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

library size.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

host body temperature.description: core body temperature of the host when sample was collected

host pulse.description: resting pulse, measured as beats per minute

dermatology disorder.description: history of dermatology disorders; can include multiple disorders

perturbation.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

host body site.description: name of body site where the sample was obtained from, such as a specific organ or tissue (tongue, lung etc...). For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

number of replicons.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

experimental factor.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.43) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

library construction method.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

host sex.description: Gender or sex of the host.

multiplex identifiers.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

ploidy.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

host disease status.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

relevant standard operating procedures.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences

pcr primers.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

known pathogenicity.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

host body-mass index.description: body mass index, calculated as weight/(height)squared

medical history performed.description: whether full medical history was collected

time since last wash.description: specification of the time since last wash

relationship to oxygen.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

sample storage location.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

host total mass.description: total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host

target gene.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

host family relationship.description: relationships to other hosts in the same study; can include multiple relationships

extrachromosomal elements.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

host body product.description: substance produced by the body, e.g. stool, mucus, where the sample was obtained from. For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

library screening strategy.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

sample volume or weight for DNA extracti.description: Volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction

validationSchema.title: GSC MIxS human skin
validationSchema.author: ENA
validationSchema.description: Genomic Standards Consortium package extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from the environment where the sample was obtained. By choosing the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from a relevant subsets of the GSC terms.

perturbation.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

adapters.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

library reads sequenced.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

isolation and growth condition.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

host body temperature.description: core body temperature of the host when sample was collected

pcr conditions.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

birth control.description: specification of birth control medication used

pcr primers.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

encoded traits.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

library construction method.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

host last meal.description: content of last meal and time since feeding; can include multiple values

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

host phenotype.description: phenotype of host. For Phenotypic quality Ontology (PATO) (v 2013-10-28) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

target gene.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

temperature.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

investigation type.description: Nucleic Acid Sequence Report is the root element of all MIxS compliant reports as standardised by Genomic Standards Consortium

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

chimera check.description: A chimeric sequence, or chimera for short, is a sequence comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences. Chimeras are usually PCR artifacts thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to a foreign DNA strand and is copied to completion in the following PCR cycles. The point at which the chimeric sequence changes from one parent to the next is called the breakpoint or conversion point

HRT.description: whether subject had hormone replacement theraphy, and if yes start date

observed biotic relationship.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

target subfragment.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

human vaginal environmental package.description: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. All environmental packages listed here are further defined in separate subtables. By giving the name of the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from the subtables and can be reported

library size.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

ploidy.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

host sex.description: Gender or sex of the host.

sexual activity.description: current sexual partner and frequency of sex

host body-mass index.description: body mass index, calculated as weight/(height)squared

host body site.description: name of body site where the sample was obtained from, such as a specific organ or tissue (tongue, lung etc...). For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

nucleic acid amplification.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

nucleic acid extraction.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

sequencing method.description: Sequencing method used; e.g. Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid

estimated size.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

gynecological disorder.description: history of gynecological disorders; can include multiple disorders

host family relationship.description: relationships to other hosts in the same study; can include multiple relationships

relevant standard operating procedures.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences

host pulse.description: resting pulse, measured as beats per minute

source material identifiers.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

subspecific genetic lineage.description: This should provide further information about the genetic distinctness of this lineage by recording additional information i.e biovar, serovar, serotype, biovar, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. It can also contain alternative taxonomic information

sequence quality check.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

host age.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

host subject id.description: a unique identifier by which each subject can be referred to, de-identified, e.g. #131

sample salinity.description: salinity of sample, i.e. measure of total salt concentration

number of replicons.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

host total mass.description: total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host

miscellaneous parameter.description: Any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here

host disease status.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

experimental factor.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.43) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

chemical administration.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

host occupation.description: most frequent job performed by subject

urogenital disorder.description: history of urogenital disorders, can include multiple disorders

organism count.description: total count of any organism per gram or volume of sample, should include name of organism followed by count; can include multiple organism counts

annotation source.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

library vector.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

propagation.description: This field is specific to different taxa. For plants: sexual/asexual, for phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, plasmids and viruses.

sample volume or weight for DNA extracti.description: Volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction

medical history performed.description: whether full medical history was collected

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

host body product.description: substance produced by the body, e.g. stool, mucus, where the sample was obtained from. For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

sample collection device or method.description: The method or deviced employed for collecting the sample

hysterectomy.description: specification of whether hysterectomy was performed

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

sample storage location.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

project name.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized
