description: ENA implementation of plant specimen contextual information associated with molecular data. The checklist has been developed in collaboration with the NCBI-GenBank and iPlant data resources under the umbrella of the Genomic Standards Consortium.

validationSchema.description: ENA implementation of plant specimen contextual information associated with molecular data. The checklist has been developed in collaboration with the NCBI-GenBank and iPlant data resources under the umbrella of the Genomic Standards Consortium.

sample material processing.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

biotic regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of biotic factors, such as bacteria, viruses or fungi

rooting medium regulators.description: growth regulators in the culture rooting medium, such as cytokinins, auxins, gybberellins, abscisic acid; e.g. 0.5mg/L NAA

soil_taxonomic/local classification meth.description: reference or method used in determining the local soil classification

growth hormone regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of growth hormone, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple growth hormone regimens

biological status.description: the level of genome modification; controlled vocabulary: wild, natural, semi-natural, inbred line, breeder's line, hybrid, clonal selection, mutant

pesticide regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of insecticides; should include the name of pesticide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple pesticide regimens

sample disease status.description: list of diseases with which the subject has been diagnosed at the time of sample collection; can include multiple diagnoses; the value of the field depends on subject; e.g. Charcoal rot (Macrophomina phaseolina), Late wilt (Cephalosporium maydis)

subspecific genetic lineage name.description: name of the infraspecific rank, e.g ecotype Col-0

geographic location (elevation).description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

ploidy.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

ancestral data.description: information about either pedigree or other description of ancestral information (e.g. parental variety in case of mutant or selection), e.g. A/3*B (meaning [(A x B) x B] x B)

salt regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media; should include the name of salt, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple salt regimens

plant structure.description: name of plant structure that the sample was obtained from; for Plant Ontology (PO) terms see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PO, e.g. petiole epidermis (PO_0000051); if an individual flower is sampled the sex of it can be recorded here

light regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to light, this includes both light intensity and quality

fungicide regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of fungicides; should include the name of fungicide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple fungicide regimens

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

sample collection device or method.description: The method or deviced employed for collecting the sample

texture method.description: reference or method used in determining soil texture

soil pH.description: pH measurement of the soil; e.g. 6.2

standing water regimen.description: treatment involving an exposure to standing water during a plant's life span, types can be flood water or standing water; can include multiple regimens

geographic location (depth).description: Depth is defined as the vertical distance below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

propagation.description: This field is specific to different taxa. For plants: sexual/asexual, for phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, plasmids and viruses.

extrachromosomal elements.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

chemical mutagen.description: treatment involving use of mutagens; should include the name of mutagen, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple mutagen regimens

pH regimen.description: information about treatment involving exposure of plants to varying levels of pH of the growth media; can include multiple regimen

organism phenotype.description: most relevant phenotypic traits of the subject; for Phenotypic quality Ontology (PATO) (v 2013-10-28) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO, e.g. bifurcated (PATO_0001784); terms from Trait Ontology (TO), Plant Ontology (PO) or Crop Ontology (CO) are also accepted; include name/method/scale for each trait; can include multiple traits

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

rooting medium macronutrients.description: measurement of the culture rooting medium macronutrients (N,P, K, Ca, Mg, S); e.g. KH2PO4 (170mg/L)

plant growth medium.description: specification of the media for growing the plants or tissue cultured samples, e.g. soil, aeroponic, hydroponic, in vitro solid culture medium, in vitro liquid culture medium, recommended value is a specific value from EO:plant growth medium or other controlled vocabulary

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

rooting medium carbon.description: source of organic carbon in the culture rooting medium; e.g. sucrose

sample disease stage.description: stage of the disease at the time of sample collection, e.g. inoculation, penetration, infection, growth and reproduction, dissemination of pathogen

estimated size.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

rooting medium pH.description: pH measurement of the culture rooting medium; e.g. 5.5

water temperature regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to water with varying degree of temperature; can include multiple regimens

soil_taxonomic/FAO classification.description: soil classification from the FAO World Reference Database for Soil Resources

collected_by.description: name of persons or institute who collected the specimen

identified_by.description: name of the expert who identified the specimen taxonomically

gaseous environment.description: use of conditions with differing gaseous environments; should include the name of gaseous compound, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple gaseous environment regimens

sampled age.description: age of subject at the time of sample collection; relevant scale depends on species and study; e.g. 2 weeks old

sample length.description: length of subject at the time of sampling, if different from the height; e.g. 2m

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

rooting conditions.description: relevant rooting conditions, such as field plot size, sowing density, container dimensions, number of plants per container

plant developmental stage.description: developmental stage at the time of sample collection; for Plant Ontology (PO) (v 20) terms, see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PO, e.g. hypocotyl emergence stage (PO_0007043)

mineral nutrient regimen.description: information about treatment involving the use of mineral supplements; should include the name of mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple mineral nutrient regimens

isolation and growth condition.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

biotic relationship.description: free text description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associate with, e.g., parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y, the target organism is the subject of the relationship, and the other organism(s) is the object

rooting medium organic supplements.description: organic supplements of the culture rooting medium, such as vitaimins, amino acids, organic acids, antibiotics activated charcoal; e.g. Nicotinic acid (0.5mg/L)

radiation regimen.description: information about treatment involving exposure of plant or a plant part to a particular radiation regimen; should include the radiation type, amount or intensity administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple radiation regimens

fertilizer regimen.description: information about treatment involving the use of fertilizers; should include the name fertilizer, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple fertilizer regimens

soil_taxonomic/local classification.description: soil classification based on local soil classification system

culture rooting medium.description: name or reference for the hydroponic or in vitro culture rooting medium, can be a name of a commonly used medium or reference to a specific medium; e.g. Murashige and Skoog medium, if the medium has not been formally published, use the rooting medium descriptors

sample height.description: height of subject at the time of sampling, if different from the length; e.g. 0.75m

plant treatment.description: ontology term(s) that describes the plant treatment or relevant environmental conditions, recommend use of Plant Environment Ontology (EO) or other ontology, such as XEML Environment Ontology (XEO) or Crop Ontology (CO), more specific fields in the treatment section can be used in addition to or in place of this field

genetic modification.description: A genetic modification of the genome of an organism which may occur naturally by spontaneous mutation, or be introduced by some experimental means. Examples of genetic modification include specification of a transgene or the gene knocked-out or details of transient transfection.

source material description.description: further information to clarify the nature of the specimen or population used that is not collected elsewhere, e.g. if source was derived from accessioned stock, describe how it links to the original material

sample storage location.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

geographic location (altitude).description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

growth facility.description: type of facility where the sampled plant was grown

watering regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to watering frequencies; can include multiple regimens

soil type method.description: reference or method used in determining soil series name or other lower-level classification

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

climate environment.description: treatment involving an exposure to a particular climate; can include multiple climates

source material identifiers.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

sample health state.description: health status of the subject at the time of sample collection

sample storage duration.description: duration for which sample was stored

growth habit.description: characteristic shape, appearance or growth form of a plant species

chemical administration.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

gravity.description: information about treatment involving use of gravity factor to study various types of responses in presence, absence or modified levels of gravity; can include multiple treatments

plant sex.description: sex of the reproductive parts on the whole plant, e.g. pistilate, staminate, monoecieous, hermaphrodite

rooting medium solidifier.description: specification of the solidifying agent in the culture rooting medium; e.g. agar

number of replicons.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

texture.description: the relative proportion of different grain sizes of mineral particles in a soil, as described using a standard system; express as % sand (50 um to 2 mm), silt (2 um to 50 um), and clay (<2 um) with textural name (e.g., silty clay loam) optional.

amount or size of sample collected.description: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected

humidity regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to varying degree of humidity; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include amount of humidity administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple regimens

sample volume or weight for DNA extracti.description: Volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction

rooting medium micronutrients.description: measurement of the culture rooting medium micronutrients (Fe, Mn, Zn, B, Cu, Mo); e.g. H3BO3 (6.2mg/L)

perturbation.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

mechanical damage.description: information about any mechanical damage exerted on the plant; can include multiple damages and sites

seasonal environment.description: treatment involving an exposure to a particular season (e.g. winter, summer, rabi, rainy etc.)

herbicide regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of herbicides; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of herbicide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple regimens

antibiotic regimen.description: information about treatment involving antibiotic administration; should include the name of antibiotic, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple antibiotic regimens

genotype.description: name or code for genotype of organism

sample phenotype.description: phenotype of the plant from which the sample was obtained, such as colour of corolla, fruit diameter, circular leaf shape; Plant Trait Ontology (TO), Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), or other ontology is recommended; e.g. stem epidermis colour (TO:1000018)

non-mineral nutrient regimen.description: information about treatment involving the exposure of plant to non-mineral nutrient such as oxygen, hydrogen or carbon; should include the name of non-mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple non-mineral nutrient regimens

air temperature regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to varying temperatures; should include the temperature, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include different temperature regimens

sample dry mass.description: measurement of dry mass at the time of sample collection; e.g. 0.05g

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

drainage classification.description: drainage classification from a standard system such as the USDA system

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

rainfall regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to a given amount of rainfall; can include multiple regimens

organism common name.description: common name of the subject organism, e.g. maize

soil type.description: soil series name or other lower-level classification

sample wet mass.description: measurement of wet mass at the time of sample collection; e.g. 0.23 g

subspecific genetic lineage rank.description: further information about the genetic distinctness of this lineage by recording additional information i.e. variety, cultivar, ecotype, inbred line,; it can also contain alternative taxonomic information

validationSchema.title: ENA Plant Sample Checklist
validationSchema.author: ENA

ploidy.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

number of replicons.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

extrachromosomal elements.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

estimated size.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

sample volume or weight for DNA extracti.description: Volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction

collected_by.description: name of persons or institute who collected the specimen

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

geographic location (altitude).description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

identified_by.description: name of the expert who identified the specimen taxonomically

geographic location (depth).description: Depth is defined as the vertical distance below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

geographic location (elevation).description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

source material identifiers.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

sample collection device or method.description: The method or deviced employed for collecting the sample

sample material processing.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2013-10-25) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

isolation and growth condition.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

propagation.description: This field is specific to different taxa. For plants: sexual/asexual, for phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, plasmids and viruses.

amount or size of sample collected.description: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected

sample storage duration.description: duration for which sample was stored

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

sample storage location.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

plant structure.description: name of plant structure that the sample was obtained from; for Plant Ontology (PO) terms see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PO, e.g. petiole epidermis (PO_0000051); if an individual flower is sampled the sex of it can be recorded here

plant developmental stage.description: developmental stage at the time of sample collection; for Plant Ontology (PO) (v 20) terms, see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PO, e.g. hypocotyl emergence stage (PO_0007043)

sampled age.description: age of subject at the time of sample collection; relevant scale depends on species and study; e.g. 2 weeks old

sample phenotype.description: phenotype of the plant from which the sample was obtained, such as colour of corolla, fruit diameter, circular leaf shape; Plant Trait Ontology (TO), Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), or other ontology is recommended; e.g. stem epidermis colour (TO:1000018)

sample health state.description: health status of the subject at the time of sample collection

sample disease status.description: list of diseases with which the subject has been diagnosed at the time of sample collection; can include multiple diagnoses; the value of the field depends on subject; e.g. Charcoal rot (Macrophomina phaseolina), Late wilt (Cephalosporium maydis)

sample disease stage.description: stage of the disease at the time of sample collection, e.g. inoculation, penetration, infection, growth and reproduction, dissemination of pathogen

sample wet mass.description: measurement of wet mass at the time of sample collection; e.g. 0.23 g

sample dry mass.description: measurement of dry mass at the time of sample collection; e.g. 0.05g

sample height.description: height of subject at the time of sampling, if different from the length; e.g. 0.75m

sample length.description: length of subject at the time of sampling, if different from the height; e.g. 2m

growth facility.description: type of facility where the sampled plant was grown

genotype.description: name or code for genotype of organism

genetic modification.description: A genetic modification of the genome of an organism which may occur naturally by spontaneous mutation, or be introduced by some experimental means. Examples of genetic modification include specification of a transgene or the gene knocked-out or details of transient transfection.

organism common name.description: common name of the subject organism, e.g. maize

subspecific genetic lineage rank.description: further information about the genetic distinctness of this lineage by recording additional information i.e. variety, cultivar, ecotype, inbred line,; it can also contain alternative taxonomic information

subspecific genetic lineage name.description: name of the infraspecific rank, e.g ecotype Col-0

biological status.description: the level of genome modification; controlled vocabulary: wild, natural, semi-natural, inbred line, breeder's line, hybrid, clonal selection, mutant

organism phenotype.description: most relevant phenotypic traits of the subject; for Phenotypic quality Ontology (PATO) (v 2013-10-28) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO, e.g. bifurcated (PATO_0001784); terms from Trait Ontology (TO), Plant Ontology (PO) or Crop Ontology (CO) are also accepted; include name/method/scale for each trait; can include multiple traits

ancestral data.description: information about either pedigree or other description of ancestral information (e.g. parental variety in case of mutant or selection), e.g. A/3*B (meaning [(A x B) x B] x B)

source material description.description: further information to clarify the nature of the specimen or population used that is not collected elsewhere, e.g. if source was derived from accessioned stock, describe how it links to the original material

biotic relationship.description: free text description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associate with, e.g., parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y, the target organism is the subject of the relationship, and the other organism(s) is the object

growth habit.description: characteristic shape, appearance or growth form of a plant species

plant sex.description: sex of the reproductive parts on the whole plant, e.g. pistilate, staminate, monoecieous, hermaphrodite

climate environment.description: treatment involving an exposure to a particular climate; can include multiple climates

gaseous environment.description: use of conditions with differing gaseous environments; should include the name of gaseous compound, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple gaseous environment regimens

seasonal environment.description: treatment involving an exposure to a particular season (e.g. winter, summer, rabi, rainy etc.)

soil_taxonomic/FAO classification.description: soil classification from the FAO World Reference Database for Soil Resources

soil_taxonomic/local classification.description: soil classification based on local soil classification system

soil_taxonomic/local classification meth.description: reference or method used in determining the local soil classification

soil type.description: soil series name or other lower-level classification

soil type method.description: reference or method used in determining soil series name or other lower-level classification

drainage classification.description: drainage classification from a standard system such as the USDA system

texture.description: the relative proportion of different grain sizes of mineral particles in a soil, as described using a standard system; express as % sand (50 um to 2 mm), silt (2 um to 50 um), and clay (<2 um) with textural name (e.g., silty clay loam) optional.

texture method.description: reference or method used in determining soil texture

soil pH.description: pH measurement of the soil; e.g. 6.2

plant growth medium.description: specification of the media for growing the plants or tissue cultured samples, e.g. soil, aeroponic, hydroponic, in vitro solid culture medium, in vitro liquid culture medium, recommended value is a specific value from EO:plant growth medium or other controlled vocabulary

rooting conditions.description: relevant rooting conditions, such as field plot size, sowing density, container dimensions, number of plants per container

culture rooting medium.description: name or reference for the hydroponic or in vitro culture rooting medium, can be a name of a commonly used medium or reference to a specific medium; e.g. Murashige and Skoog medium, if the medium has not been formally published, use the rooting medium descriptors

rooting medium macronutrients.description: measurement of the culture rooting medium macronutrients (N,P, K, Ca, Mg, S); e.g. KH2PO4 (170mg/L)

rooting medium micronutrients.description: measurement of the culture rooting medium micronutrients (Fe, Mn, Zn, B, Cu, Mo); e.g. H3BO3 (6.2mg/L)

rooting medium organic supplements.description: organic supplements of the culture rooting medium, such as vitaimins, amino acids, organic acids, antibiotics activated charcoal; e.g. Nicotinic acid (0.5mg/L)

rooting medium carbon.description: source of organic carbon in the culture rooting medium; e.g. sucrose

rooting medium regulators.description: growth regulators in the culture rooting medium, such as cytokinins, auxins, gybberellins, abscisic acid; e.g. 0.5mg/L NAA

rooting medium solidifier.description: specification of the solidifying agent in the culture rooting medium; e.g. agar

rooting medium pH.description: pH measurement of the culture rooting medium; e.g. 5.5

air temperature regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to varying temperatures; should include the temperature, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include different temperature regimens

antibiotic regimen.description: information about treatment involving antibiotic administration; should include the name of antibiotic, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple antibiotic regimens

chemical mutagen.description: treatment involving use of mutagens; should include the name of mutagen, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple mutagen regimens

fertilizer regimen.description: information about treatment involving the use of fertilizers; should include the name fertilizer, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple fertilizer regimens

fungicide regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of fungicides; should include the name of fungicide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple fungicide regimens

gravity.description: information about treatment involving use of gravity factor to study various types of responses in presence, absence or modified levels of gravity; can include multiple treatments

growth hormone regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of growth hormone, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple growth hormone regimens

herbicide regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of herbicides; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of herbicide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple regimens

humidity regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to varying degree of humidity; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include amount of humidity administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple regimens

mineral nutrient regimen.description: information about treatment involving the use of mineral supplements; should include the name of mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple mineral nutrient regimens

non-mineral nutrient regimen.description: information about treatment involving the exposure of plant to non-mineral nutrient such as oxygen, hydrogen or carbon; should include the name of non-mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple non-mineral nutrient regimens

pesticide regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of insecticides; should include the name of pesticide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple pesticide regimens

pH regimen.description: information about treatment involving exposure of plants to varying levels of pH of the growth media; can include multiple regimen

radiation regimen.description: information about treatment involving exposure of plant or a plant part to a particular radiation regimen; should include the radiation type, amount or intensity administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple radiation regimens

rainfall regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to a given amount of rainfall; can include multiple regimens

salt regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media; should include the name of salt, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple salt regimens

standing water regimen.description: treatment involving an exposure to standing water during a plant's life span, types can be flood water or standing water; can include multiple regimens

watering regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to watering frequencies; can include multiple regimens

water temperature regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to water with varying degree of temperature; can include multiple regimens

plant treatment.description: ontology term(s) that describes the plant treatment or relevant environmental conditions, recommend use of Plant Environment Ontology (EO) or other ontology, such as XEML Environment Ontology (XEO) or Crop Ontology (CO), more specific fields in the treatment section can be used in addition to or in place of this field

light regimen.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to light, this includes both light intensity and quality

biotic regimen.description: information about treatment involving use of biotic factors, such as bacteria, viruses or fungi

mechanical damage.description: information about any mechanical damage exerted on the plant; can include multiple damages and sites

chemical administration.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

perturbation.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

description: Shellfish contextual information associated with molecular data. The checklist has been developed in collaboration with EMBRIC Project partners.

validationSchema.title: ENA Shellfish Checklist
validationSchema.description: Shellfish contextual information associated with molecular data. The checklist has been developed in collaboration with EMBRIC Project partners.

gonad weight.description: Total weight of entire gonad tissue

shell width.description: width of shell (perpendicular angle to length)

Depth.description: The distance below the surface of the water at which a measurement was made or a sample was collected. Format: ####.##, Positive below the sea surface. SDN:P06:46:ULAA for m. Example: 14.71

shell length.description: length of shell (perpendicular to the hinge)

treatment agent.description: The name of the treatment agent used.

Sampling Station.description: Refers to the site/station where data/sample collection is performed. Example: TARA_100.

Sample Collection Device.description: The sampling device(s) used for the Event. Example: CTD(sbe9C)/Rosette with Niskin bottles.

sample disease status.description: list of diseases with which the subject has been diagnosed at the time of sample collection; can include multiple diagnoses; the value of the field depends on subject; e.g. Charcoal rot (Macrophomina phaseolina), Late wilt (Cephalosporium maydis)

storage conditions (fresh/frozen/other).description: explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before DNA extraction.

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

Sampling Campaign.description: Refers to a finite or indefinite activity aiming at collecting data/samples, e.g. a cruise, a time series, a mesocosm experiment. Example: TARA_20110401Z.

age.description: Age of the organism the sample was derived from.

Event Date/Time.description: Date and time in UTC when the sampling event started and ended, e.g. each CTD cast, net tow, or bucket collection is a distinct event. Format: yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ssZ. Example: 2013-06-21T14:05:00Z/2013-06-21T14:46:00Z.

shellfish soft tissue weight.description: Total weight of all soft tissue, i.e. weight of entire organism without shell, at the time of sampling

seabed habitat.description: Classification of the seabed where the organism has been found; for European seabed habitats please use terms from http://eunis.eea.europa.eu/habitats-code-browser.jsp; example: B3.4 : Soft sea-cliffs, often vegetated

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

sample health state.description: health status of the subject at the time of sample collection

Latitude Start.description: Latitude of the location where the sampling event started, e.g. each CTD cast, net tow, or bucket collection is a distinct event. Format: ##.####, Decimal degrees; North= +, South= -; Use WGS 84 for GPS data. Example: -24.6666.

Sampling Platform.description: Refers to the unique stage from which the sampling device has been deployed. Includes Platform category from SDN:L06, http://seadatanet.maris2.nl/v_bodc_vocab_v2/search.asp?lib=L06, and Platform name. Example: Research Vessel Tara.

adductor weight.description: Total weight of striated muscle and smooth muscle

Protocol Label.description: Identifies the protocol used to produce the sample, e.g. filtration and preservation. Example: BACT_NUC_W0.22-1.6.

toxin burden.description: Concentration of toxins in the organism at the time of sampling

aquaculture origin.description: Origin of stock and raised conditions

Marine Region.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the marine region name chosen from the Marine Regions vocabulary at http://www.marineregions.org/. Example: Aegean Sea.

shellfish total weight.description: Total weight of shellfish including shell at the time of sampling. Epifauna and epiphytes to be removed.

Longitude Start.description: Longitude of the location where the sampling event started, e.g. each CTD cast, net tow, or bucket collection is a distinct event. Format: ###.####, Decimal degrees; East= +, West= -; Use WGS 84 for GPS data. Example: -096.1012.

chemical compound.description: A drug, solvent, chemical, etc., with a property that can be measured such as concentration (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_37577).

validationSchema.author: ENA

Event Date/Time.description: Date and time in UTC when the sampling event started and ended, e.g. each CTD cast, net tow, or bucket collection is a distinct event. Format: yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ssZ. Example: 2013-06-21T14:05:00Z/2013-06-21T14:46:00Z.

Latitude Start.description: Latitude of the location where the sampling event started, e.g. each CTD cast, net tow, or bucket collection is a distinct event. Format: ##.####, Decimal degrees; North= +, South= -; Use WGS 84 for GPS data. Example: -24.6666.

Longitude Start.description: Longitude of the location where the sampling event started, e.g. each CTD cast, net tow, or bucket collection is a distinct event. Format: ###.####, Decimal degrees; East= +, West= -; Use WGS 84 for GPS data. Example: -096.1012.

Depth.description: The distance below the surface of the water at which a measurement was made or a sample was collected. Format: ####.##, Positive below the sea surface. SDN:P06:46:ULAA for m. Example: 14.71

Sample Collection Device.description: The sampling device(s) used for the Event. Example: CTD(sbe9C)/Rosette with Niskin bottles.

Protocol Label.description: Identifies the protocol used to produce the sample, e.g. filtration and preservation. Example: BACT_NUC_W0.22-1.6.

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

Sampling Campaign.description: Refers to a finite or indefinite activity aiming at collecting data/samples, e.g. a cruise, a time series, a mesocosm experiment. Example: TARA_20110401Z.

Sampling Station.description: Refers to the site/station where data/sample collection is performed. Example: TARA_100.

Sampling Platform.description: Refers to the unique stage from which the sampling device has been deployed. Includes Platform category from SDN:L06, http://seadatanet.maris2.nl/v_bodc_vocab_v2/search.asp?lib=L06, and Platform name. Example: Research Vessel Tara.

storage conditions (fresh/frozen/other).description: explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before DNA extraction.

sample health state.description: health status of the subject at the time of sample collection

sample disease status.description: list of diseases with which the subject has been diagnosed at the time of sample collection; can include multiple diagnoses; the value of the field depends on subject; e.g. Charcoal rot (Macrophomina phaseolina), Late wilt (Cephalosporium maydis)

Marine Region.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the marine region name chosen from the Marine Regions vocabulary at http://www.marineregions.org/. Example: Aegean Sea.

seabed habitat.description: Classification of the seabed where the organism has been found; for European seabed habitats please use terms from http://eunis.eea.europa.eu/habitats-code-browser.jsp; example: B3.4 : Soft sea-cliffs, often vegetated

age.description: Age of the organism the sample was derived from.

aquaculture origin.description: Origin of stock and raised conditions

shellfish total weight.description: Total weight of shellfish including shell at the time of sampling. Epifauna and epiphytes to be removed.

shellfish soft tissue weight.description: Total weight of all soft tissue, i.e. weight of entire organism without shell, at the time of sampling

shell length.description: length of shell (perpendicular to the hinge)

shell width.description: width of shell (perpendicular angle to length)

adductor weight.description: Total weight of striated muscle and smooth muscle

gonad weight.description: Total weight of entire gonad tissue

toxin burden.description: Concentration of toxins in the organism at the time of sampling

treatment agent.description: The name of the treatment agent used.

chemical compound.description: A drug, solvent, chemical, etc., with a property that can be measured such as concentration (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_37577).

dev_stage.description: if the sample was obtained from an organism in a specific developmental stage, it is specified with this qualifier

subject exposure.description: Exposure of the subject to infected human or animals, such as poultry, wild bird or swine. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon. Example: poultry; wild bird

subject exposure duration.description: Duration of the exposure of the subject to an infected human or animal. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state their duration in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. Example: 1 day; 0.33 days

travel-relation.description: Designates the relation of the main diagnosis to the patient's travel.

clinical setting.description: The timing of the clinic visit in relation to travel.

country of travel.description: The name of the country of patient's travel.

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

genotype.description: name or code for genotype of organism

host common name.description: common name of the host, e.g. human

host subject id.description: a unique identifier by which each subject can be referred to, de-identified, e.g. #131

host age.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

host health state.description: Health status of the host at the time of sample collection.

host sex.description: Gender or sex of the host.

host scientific name.description: Scientific name of the natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which sample was obtained.

collector name.description: Name of the person who collected the specimen. Example: John Smith

collecting institution.description: Name of the institution to which the person collecting the specimen belongs. Format: Institute Name, Institute Address

sample storage conditions.description: Conditions at which sample was stored, usually storage temperature, duration and location

isolate.description: individual isolate from which the sample was obtained

strain.description: Name of the strain from which the sample was obtained.

isolation source host-associated.description: Name of host tissue or organ sampled for analysis. Example: tracheal tissue

diagnostic method.description: The method or procedure (imaging, genetic or other) performed to determine or confirm the presence of disease in an individual. Examples: microscopy, immunofluorescence, PCR, rapid tests, etc.

known pathogenicity.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

isolation source non-host-associated.description: Describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived. Example: soil

description: Minimum information about parasite samples. A checklist for reporting metadata of parasite samples associated with molecular data. This standard was developed by the COMPARE platform and can be used for submission of sample metadata derived from protozoan parasites (e.g. Cryptosporidium) and also multicellular eukaryotic parasites (e.g. Platyhelminthes and Nematoda).

validationSchema.description: Minimum information about parasite samples. A checklist for reporting metadata of parasite samples associated with molecular data. This standard was developed by the COMPARE platform and can be used for submission of sample metadata derived from protozoan parasites (e.g. Cryptosporidium) and also multicellular eukaryotic parasites (e.g. Platyhelminthes and Nematoda).

description: Minimum information required for reporting samples associated with the UniEuk EukBank initiative. This checklist aims to capture contextual metadata associated with V4 18S SSU rRNA molecular data.

Size Fraction Lower Threshold.description: SAMPLE_PROTOCOL_Size-Fraction_Lower-Threshold_(µm) indicates the lower size threshold. Materials smaller than the size threshold are excluded from the sample. Example: 0.22 µm

Size Fraction Upper Threshold.description: SAMPLE_PROTOCOL_Size-Fraction_Upper-Threshold_(µm) indicates the upper size threshold. Materials larger than the size threshold are excluded from the sample.Example: 1.6 µm

target gene.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

target subfragment.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

pcr primers.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

isolation_source.description: describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived

collected_by.description: name of persons or institute who collected the specimen

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

geographic location (altitude).description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

geographic location (depth).description: Depth is defined as the vertical distance below surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectivly. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

environment (biome).description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (feature).description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

environment (material).description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO

sample collection device or method.description: The method or deviced employed for collecting the sample

environmental_sample.description: identifies sequences derived by direct molecular isolation from a bulk environmental DNA sample (by PCR with or without subsequent cloning of the product, DGGE, or other anonymous methods) with no reliable identification of the source organism

Salinity.description: Salinity of water at the time of taking the sample. Format: ##.#, SDN:P02::PSAL, SDN:P06::UGKG for PSU. Example: 39.1 psu.

Further Details.description: Reference details related to a sample in form of an URI.

description: Minimum information to standardise metadata related to samples used in GMI PT (Global Microbial Identifier Proficiency Test). A checklist for reporting metadata of GMI PT samples associated with molecular data. This minimum metadata standard was developed by the COMPARE platform and can be used for submission of sample metadata derived from Campylobacter coli, Campylobacter jejuni, Listeria monocytogenes, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Salmonella enterica, Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus.
displayName: ENA Global Microbial Identifier Proficiency Test (GMI PT) checklist

nucleic acid extraction.description: Link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP)

library construction method.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

protocol.description: The laboratory method used to reveal the presence of the sample sequenced in the experiment.

instrument for DNA concentration measure.description: Name/type of instrument used to measure the DNA concentration (ng/µl) prior to library preparation

read quality filter.description: Programme used to filter reads quality before conducting the analysis

DNA concentration.description: DNA concentration used for sequencing in ng/µl

collection_date.description: date that the specimen was collected

isolation_source.description: describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

amount or size of sample collected.description: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected

sample storage duration.description: duration for which sample was stored

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

sample storage location.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

sample transportation temperature.description: transportation temperature from sample site to storage

sample transportation date.description: transportation/shipping date of the sample. Format:YYYY-MM-DD

sample transportation time.description: transportation time from sample site to storage

receipt date.description: Date on which the sample was received. Format:YYYY-MM-DD. Please provide the highest precision possible. If the sample was received by the institution and not collected, the 'receipt date' must be provided instead. Either the 'collection date' or 'receipt date' must be provided. If available, provide both dates.

links to additional analysis.description: link to additional analysis results performed on the sample

isolate.description: individual isolate from which the sample was obtained

sub_species.description: name of sub-species of organism from which sample was obtained

Further Details.description: Reference details related to a sample in form of an URI.

description: Minimum information to standardise metadata related to samples used in RNA seq experiments. Useful for downstream services to select RNA-Seq read data for appropriate alignment processing and display. Also useful for external users to select RNA-Seq read files, their alignments, and structured metadata describing the source material.

geographic location (latitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

culture_collection.description: institution code and identifier for the culture from which the sample was obtained, with optional collection code.

Depth.description: The distance below the surface of the water at which a measurement was made or a sample was collected. Format: ####.##, Positive below the sea surface. SDN:P06:46:ULAA for m. Example: 14.71

collected_by.description: name of persons or institute who collected the specimen

Temperature.description: Temperature of water at the time of taking the sample. Format: ##.####, SDN:P02:75:TEMP, SDN:P06:46:UPAA for °C. Example: 17.7122.

geographic location (longitude).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

collection date.description: The date of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

isolation and growth condition.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

strain.description: Name of the strain from which the sample was obtained.

sample storage temperature.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

growth condition.description: A role that a material entity can play which enables particular conditions used to grow organisms or parts of the organism. This includes isolated environments such as cultures and open environments such as field studies.

sample storage conditions.description: Conditions at which sample was stored, usually storage temperature, duration and location

Salinity.description: Salinity of water at the time of taking the sample. Format: ##.#, SDN:P02::PSAL, SDN:P06::UGKG for PSU. Example: 39.1 psu.

description: Marine microalgae contextual information. The checklist has been developed in collaboration with EMBRIC Project partners and is suitable for reporting metadata related to environmental samples and those in culture collections.

subject exposure.description: Exposure of the subject to infected human or animals, such as poultry, wild bird or swine. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon. Example: poultry; wild bird

subject exposure duration.description: Duration of the exposure of the subject to an infected human or animal. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state their duration in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. Example: 1 day; 0.33 days

travel-relation.description: Designates the relation of the main diagnosis to the patient's travel.

clinical setting.description: The timing of the clinic visit in relation to travel.

country of travel.description: The name of the country of patient's travel.

collection_date.description: date that the specimen was collected

collected_by.description: name of persons or institute who collected the specimen

geographic location (country and/or sea).description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

geographic location (region and locality.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

host disease status.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

host scientific name.description: Scientific name of the natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which sample was obtained.

isolate.description: individual isolate from which the sample was obtained

sub_type.description: name of sub-type of organism from which sample was obtained

serovar.description: serological variety of a species (usually a prokaryote) characterized by its antigenic properties

serovar_in-silico.description: serological variety of a species characterized by its antigenic properties derived by in silico prediction

isolation source host-associated.description: Name of host tissue or organ sampled for analysis. Example: tracheal tissue

description: A checklist for reporting metadata of human-associated pathogen samples for the COMPARE-ECDC-EFSA reporting system.

If available, provide both dates.
